section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: A hands-on programming section that introduces the fundamental building blocks of Python code. Students will learn how to store and manipulate data using variables, explore the core data types, and understand how to perform basic operations.
learning_objectives: Define and assign values to variables using Python syntax
Identify and utilize the core data types: integers, floats, strings, and booleans
Perform basic arithmetic and string operations
Convert between different data types using type casting
Apply variables and data types to solve simple programming problems

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create variables, assign different data types to them, and print their values to the console.
key_topics: Variable assignment syntax using the equals sign (=)
Naming conventions and rules for variables
Using the print() function to display variable contents
Reassigning new values to existing variables

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create three variables: one holding your age, one holding your name, and one holding your favorite color. Print each variable's value.
Create a variable called 'score' and assign it the value 10. Print it. Then, reassign it to 15 and print it again.

lessons.lesson_title: Working with Numbers: Integers and Floats
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to perform arithmetic operations with integer and float data types and understand the difference between them.
key_topics: Integer data type for whole numbers
Float data type for decimal numbers
Basic arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /)
Exponentiation (**) and floor division (//)
Modulo operator (%) for finding remainders

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create two variables with numeric values. Perform and print the result of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division on these variables.
Write a program that calculates how many slices of pizza each person gets if 8 people share 30 slices equally, and how many slices will be left over.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create string variables, concatenate them, and use basic string methods.
key_topics: String creation using single, double, and triple quotes
String concatenation using the plus (+) operator
String methods: .upper(), .lower(), .title()
Finding the length of a string with len()
Basic string indexing to access individual characters

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for a first name and a last name. Concatenate them to form a full name and print a greeting message like 'Hello, John Doe!'.
Take a user-provided sentence (hard-coded for now) and print it in all uppercase, all lowercase, and title case.

lessons.lesson_title: Making Decisions with Booleans and Comparisons
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to use boolean data types and comparison operators to evaluate conditions.
key_topics: Boolean values: True and False
Comparison operators (==, !=, >, <, >=, <=)
Using the input() function to get user data
Checking data types with the type() function

exercises.exercise_instructions: Ask the user for their age. Convert the input to an integer and check if they are 18 or older. Print True or False based on the result.
Ask the user for two numbers. Print whether the first number is greater than, less than, or equal to the second number.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert data between strings, integers, and floats using type casting functions.
key_topics: Type casting functions: str(), int(), float()
Converting user input from string to numbers
Handling errors when conversion is not possible
Embedding numbers within strings using f-strings

exercises.exercise_instructions: Ask the user for their age. Convert the input to an integer and calculate the year they were born. Print the result in a full sentence using an f-string.
Create a string variable with the value '123.45'. Convert it to a float, then convert that float to an integer. Print both the float and integer values.
